company.entity_resolution_notes: Proff identifies the entity as 7 STEEL NORDIC MANUFACTURING AS with org.nr 953 591 421 [1]. LEI data tied to Brønnøysund registration ID 953 591 421 lists CELSA ARMERINGSSTÅL AS as a previous legal name, supporting continuity after renaming [5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: The company uses ferrous steel scrap as core inbound feedstock for electric-arc-furnace steelmaking; sources describe scrap-based production and annual recycling volumes above 700,000 tonnes [2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Ferrous steel scrap
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as the main metallic feedstock in electric arc furnace steel production at Mo i Rana [2][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence describes steel production based on scrap metal and reports more than 700,000 tonnes of scrap recycled per year, indicating this is core rather than pilot use [3][4].

main_quantity.context: A public statement about Celsa Armeringsstål (previous legal name linked to same registration ID) reports annual recycling of over 700,000 tonnes of scrap metal [3][5].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The quantified figure is stated as "over 700 000 tonn" and not tied to a specific reporting year in the source text [3]. EPD text confirms scrap-based steelmaking inputs but does not provide audited annual tonnes for the legal entity [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: No directly accessed annual/sustainability report for this exact legal entity provided a current-year audited SRM input mass; quantity therefore relies on a press release statement and supporting EPD process description [3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source found in this review provided a legal-entity-specific audited breakdown of scrap grades or monthly inbound SRM tonnage [3][4].
EPD evidence is tied to downstream products and references supplier process data from 7 Steel Nordic Manufacturing, so volume attribution to the legal entity is supported but indirect [4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity is identified on Proff as ALCOA NORWAY AS with org. no. 928 825 345 (AS). The same Norwegian entity publishes the 2024 annual report on Alcoa Norway pages [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Alcoa Norway AS shows evidence of inbound recycled metal input (remelt/scrap-derived aluminum) used in production. The annual report states remelt metal is added/mixed in production, and Mosjøen products include at least 50% recycled content for EcoDura-standard cast products [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled/remelt aluminum metal input
srm_inputs.used_for: Remelt/recycled aluminum is used as an inbound metal input in casting/alloy production; the report says remelt metal is added to primary production and mixed with potroom metal [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates regular operational use (not only pilot): remelt metal is part of production flows, and Mosjøen states EcoDura cast products with at least 50% recycled content [2][3].

share.context: The EcoDura requirement states at least 50% recycled content in the aluminum product; this is product-standard evidence, not company-wide average [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No public source found with company-level annual tonnage of inbound recycled/remelt metal for Alcoa Norway AS; available evidence is qualitative plus a product-level minimum share [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 50% recycled-content figure applies to EcoDura-standard cast products and does not disclose what share of total Alcoa Norway output this represents [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No disclosed company-level mass flow (t/year) for inbound recycled/remelt aluminum was identified in the reviewed public sources [2][3].
No source in scope quantified site-by-site split (Lista vs Mosjøen) of recycled metal input volumes [2][3].

Supplier categories are listed (e.g., asphalt, stone/pukk/jord), but recycled-content share or waste-derived feedstock use is not specified [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The legal entity is identified on Proff as BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS with org number 928 878 090 [1]. Proff lists Rune Kvilvang as general manager, and BEWI Food identifies Rune Kvilvang as Managing Director Norway Packaging, supporting linkage to Norwegian packaging operations [1][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates inbound use of recycled polymer feedstock in BEWI fish-box packaging offerings (GreenLine/Circulum Balance; EPS boxes based on recycled feedstock), but disclosures are mainly at BEWI group/segment level and do not provide entity-specific inbound SRM volumes for BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled polymer feedstock for EPS packaging
material_examples: Recycled feedstock in Circulum Balance EPS raw material grade
srm_inputs.used_for: BEWI states GreenLine fish boxes are produced using Circulum Balance, an EPS raw material grade based on recycled feedstock; this is described for food packaging applications [3]. The annual report also refers to EPS boxes based on recycled feedstock in the packaging portfolio [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: There is clear qualitative evidence of recycled polymer feedstock entering packaging products, but no BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS-specific annual input quantity/share is disclosed; therefore classified as minor/limited evidence at entity level [2][3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct inbound tonnage, energy, or company-specific percent share for this legal entity was found in the reviewed Norwegian/entity-linked sources; available quantified shares are reported at BEWI group level [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Sources describe BEWI group and packaging segment practices; applicability to this exact legal entity is supported by role linkage but not explicitly quantified for BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS [1][2][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No permit/EPD/product-sheet document was found that quantifies inbound recycled polymer input for BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS specifically [1][2].
Group-level KPI data on recycled material use exists, but cannot be cleanly allocated to this legal entity without additional entity-level reporting [2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Proff profile URL slug uses the historical name "Bir Avfallsenergi AS", but official company information on that same page states legal name BIR RESSURS AS with org nr 985 825 408 [1].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: BIR Ressurs AS uses incoming residual waste as a core waste-derived fuel input in its waste-to-energy operations; the company reports receiving about 200,000 tons in 2024 and converting combustion energy into heat and power [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Residual waste used as solid waste-derived fuel
material_examples: Selected combustible fractions including some hazardous fractions permitted for treatment
srm_inputs.used_for: Incoming residual waste is combusted in the Rådalen plant, where released energy is used to produce steam for electricity and district heating [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is core to operations: the company states it received about 200,000 tons of waste in 2024 and runs large-scale continuous combustion-based energy recovery [2][3].

main_quantity.context: Company reporting states approximately 200,000 tons of waste were received in 2024 at the plant [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The disclosed volume is approximate ("ca.") and reported as total incoming waste, not a fully disaggregated SRF specification by fraction [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Sources do not provide a precise split of inbound waste by composition (e.g., biogenic/fossil share, specific combustible sub-fractions), so B1 classification is based on residual waste-to-energy context [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source found in reviewed material with audited, fraction-level inbound SRM breakdown for BIR Ressurs AS (by waste type and exact SRF composition) [2][3].
No direct permit document with explicit annual input limit/actuals was retrieved; the annual-report page references permit scope at a high level [2].

employees.notes: Proff lists 1,556 employees for ELKEM ASA (parent-company figures shown on the page). [1]

revenue.notes: Proff reports "Sum driftsinntekter 2024 9 710 000" with amounts stated in thousands (NOK), i.e., NOK 9.71 billion. [1]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Proff identifies the Norwegian legal entity as ELKEM ASA with org number 911 382 008, matching the requested company. [1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates pilot/early-stage inbound SRM use: Elkem describes projects to recycle slag/silicon side streams into new products and to capture/reuse process carbon as reductant; both are framed as R&D/pilot initiatives. [2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled slag and secondary silicon streams
srm_inputs.used_for: Elkem states a 2025-2026 project to develop products by recycling slag and silicon materials, including cement alternatives and introducing recycled material streams into production. [2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes this as funded R&D with pilot testing and demonstration, not mature large-scale disclosed use. [2]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No actual annual inbound tonnage is disclosed for recycled slag/silicon inputs; only project scope and target language (e.g., >50% recycling share in newly developed products). [2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Disclosed figures are project targets and development-phase statements; company-wide realised SRM input volumes are not reported in the cited source. [2]

srm_inputs.label: Captured process carbon reused as reductant (Sicalo pilot)
srm_inputs.used_for: Elkem describes a concept where carbon in off-gases is captured and reused in silicon production as reduction material. [3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The source explicitly says this is a pilot in Kristiansand and that substantial research remains before full-scale viability. [3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No disclosed mass/energy quantity for captured carbon reused as input; status is pilot/lab/bench scale. [3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Commercial-scale implementation timeline and actual recurring input volume are not disclosed in the cited announcement. [3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source located here provides audited annual quantities of inbound SRM (t, kg, m3, or energy units) for ELKEM ASA. [2][3]
Elkem policy text indicates current biocarbon use is primarily wood-based while recycled wood is being explored, so biocarbon was not counted as confirmed SRM input in this assessment. [4]
Several cited activities are project or pilot descriptions; evidence of routine, company-wide SRM throughput is limited. [2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Proff record used is a site page (AVD PORSGRUNN) but it explicitly points to “Hovedenhet ERAMET NORWAY AS” with org. no. 980 518 647; Brønnøysund confirms ERAMET NORWAY AS with the same organisation number [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Eramet Norway shows evidence of inbound secondary inputs through internal recirculation of metallurgical by-products: ferromanganese slag is used as raw material for silicomanganese production, and furnace dust/slag are reintroduced into production processes [3][4][5]. Evidence indicates meaningful operational use, but no disclosed annual inbound SRM tonnage [3][4][5].

srm_inputs.label: Internal recirculation of ferromanganese slag and furnace dust
srm_inputs.used_for: Ferromanganese slag is used as an input in silicomanganese production in Kvinesdal, and furnace dust/slag are reintroduced into production processes [3][4][5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Company and group disclosures describe slag as an “important input factor” and state that large quantities of by-products are internally circulated/reintroduced, indicating ongoing meaningful use rather than isolated pilots [4][5].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass/energy quantity for inbound recirculated slag or furnace dust is disclosed in the reviewed public sources [3][4][5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Available disclosures are qualitative and do not separate exact inbound SRM volumes by site/year; therefore tiering is based on wording about operational importance and internal circulation [4][5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Public sources reviewed do not provide a numeric annual inbound quantity (t/year) for recirculated FeMn slag or furnace dust [3][4][5].
Disclosures mix site-level and company-level narratives, limiting precise allocation of SRM input volumes to legal-entity totals [4][5].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity was resolved as EVERZINC NORWAY AS (AS) in Larvik with organization number 967337897 on Proff.[1] The Norwegian emissions registry page for companyID 5707 also identifies the facility as EverZinc Norway in Larvik.[4]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates inbound use of secondary zinc-bearing materials for EverZinc operations, including material streams explicitly linked to the Larvik plant and municipal hearing text stating the Larvik facility processes scrap zinc for zinc recovery.[2][3] However, the quantified 40% secondary share is stated at EverZinc level and not isolated to the Norwegian entity.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Secondary zinc residues and scrap zinc
srm_inputs.used_for: These secondary zinc materials are purchased as inbound raw materials and used in EverZinc plants including Larvik; Larvik is described as processing scrap zinc for zinc recovery and producing zinc powder/zinc oxide.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes itself as a major recycler/consumer of galvanizing residues and states secondary raw materials are used in plants including Larvik, indicating meaningful operational use rather than pilot use.[2]

share.context: EverZinc states that 40% of zinc units processed come from secondary sources, but this is presented at EverZinc level and not broken out for Norway.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No Norway-entity-specific annual tonnage of inbound secondary zinc residues/scrap was found in the accessible sources; only a group-level secondary share statement was found.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 40% figure appears group-wide. Available Norwegian public pages confirm scrap-zinc processing in Larvik but do not provide site-specific inbound SRM mass/energy quantities.[2][3][4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: The accessible Norwegian emissions registry page confirms permits/control reports exist, but no directly accessible permit text with explicit inbound SRM tonnages was retrieved in this search session.[4]
Current evidence is sufficient for directionality (SRM inbound), but insufficient for robust Norway-only quantification beyond qualitative usage and one group-level percentage.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The matched Norwegian legal entity is FORESTIA AS (Aksjeselskap) with org number 981 393 961 on Proff, consistent with the Braskereidfoss industrial operation.[1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Forestia shows evidence of inbound secondary bio-based input use: wood by-products/waste-derived chips from sawmills used in chipboard production, indicating core relevance to production.[2][3] Forestia also has an ongoing return-wood project (demolition wood cleaning/reuse) supported by public funding, but operational volumes are not disclosed.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Sawmill by-product wood chips
srm_inputs.used_for: Forestia states it procures wood as by-products from sawmills for board production, and group reporting states these chips are used in chipboards.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is described as "large amounts" and directly tied to chipboard production, indicating a core production input rather than pilot use.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No Forestia-specific annual tonnage of inbound sawmill by-product chips is disclosed in the identified public sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: One statement is group-level (Byggma) and may not isolate Forestia volumes; however, Forestia-specific text confirms by-product sourcing.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Return wood (demolition wood) for new chipboard feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Forestia reports an ongoing project to clean demolition wood and recycle it into new boards/chipboard feedstock.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates an ongoing investment/project phase with support funding, but no confirmed steady-state operational input volume is provided.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: Available figures describe project support (MNOK 80) rather than measured annual inbound mass/volume of return wood.[3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Sources do not confirm actual annual processed return-wood quantities or the exact commissioning/operational status of the line.[2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No public Forestia-specific annual quantity (t, m3) for inbound secondary raw materials was found in the reviewed sources.[2][3]
No disclosed share of secondary inputs versus total wood feedstock was found.[2][3]
Project evidence for demolition wood is strong, but operational throughput and year-specific realized use remain undisclosed.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Entity resolved as the Norwegian company Glasopor AS (org.nr 884344662). Proff shows the org number and an underenhet label, while permit application documents use the same organization number for Glasopor AS. [1][2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Glasopor AS uses recycled glass waste as a core inbound feedstock for foam-glass production. Permit documentation states receipt of recycled glass streams and ~55,000 tonnes in 2022 at Onsøy, while company material pages state 100% recycled glass packaging feedstock. [2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled glass feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Recycled glass is crushed to fine powder and heat-processed (with activator) to produce foam glass used as lightweight fill and insulation material. [2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is described as fundamental to the product (foam glass made from recycled packaging glass), with substantial inbound quantity disclosed for Onsøy (about 55,000 t in 2022). [2][3]

main_quantity.context: The permit application states the Onsøy facility received about 55,000 tonnes of glass in 2022; this is a site-level inbound SRM amount. [2]

share.context: Company product information states foam glass is made from 100% recycled glass packaging; treated as feedstock share claim. [3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct mass figure is available for one site (Onsøy, 2022). No consolidated company-wide annual SRM input total was identified in available public sources. [2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Source material mix includes several recovered glass fractions, but publicly available sources do not provide fraction-by-fraction shares or latest company-wide totals. [2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No audited, consolidated SRM input tonnage for all Glasopor AS operations (beyond disclosed Onsøy site data) was found. [2]
Employee count at legal-entity level could not be confirmed from accessible Proff content, which displayed underenhet information. [1]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity is identified as GLENCORE NIKKELVERK AS with org. no. 911 575 787 on Proff, and the due diligence report names the same company in Kristiansand, Norway. [1][2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Glencore Nikkelverk confirms that part of its third-party feed includes recycled materials, and that about one-third of third-party suppliers delivered 100% recycled material in 2024. This indicates meaningful SRM input use, but available evidence is supplier-share based rather than mass/energy quantities. [2]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled metal-bearing feed materials
srm_inputs.used_for: Recycled third-party feed materials are purchased and processed at Nikkelverk Refinery as input to refining operations. [2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The report states recycled materials are part of input sourcing and that approximately one-third of third-party suppliers delivered 100% recycled material in 2024; this is beyond pilot scale but lacks volume share by mass. [2]

share.context: Reported share is approximately one-third of third-party suppliers delivering 100% recycled material, not a direct mass share of total feed. [2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct tonnage, volume, or energy quantity for recycled input is disclosed in the cited public documents. [2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The recycled-input metric is supplier-based (count of suppliers), and the specific recycled material types/compositions are not quantified in the public report excerpts. [2]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The entity was resolved as the Norwegian company Hafslund Celsio AS using matching company name and org number on Proff, cross-checked against the Miljødirektoratet permit record for Klemetsrud [1][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Hafslund Celsio uses large-scale inbound residual waste as a core feedstock in waste-to-energy operations (377,634 t burned in 2024), with permit framework up to 410,000 t/year at Klemetsrud [2][4].

srm_inputs.label: Residual waste feedstock for waste-to-energy incineration
srm_inputs.used_for: The company incinerates non-reusable/non-recyclable waste and uses the recovered heat for district heating and electricity production [2][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is core to operations: reported burned waste is 377,634 t in 2024, and permit conditions define large annual intake capacity and waste categories [2][4].

main_quantity.context: Reported as total burned waste amount across Klemetsrud and Haraldrud for 2024 [2].

other_quantities.context: Klemetsrud permit states maximum annual total waste intake [4].
Klemetsrud permit specifies annual limit for ordinary waste including household/commercial residual waste [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct annual inbound mass is disclosed for 2024 (377,634 t burned waste). Permit limits provide additional site-level envelope for Klemetsrud [2][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The public key-figures page aggregates burned waste and does not disclose detailed composition shares (e.g., recyclable vs non-recyclable fractions within received streams) [2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-wide audited SRM composition split (by waste subtype) was found in accessible public sources used here [2][4].
Support fuels are disclosed, but the sources used do not prove these are secondary raw materials, so they were excluded from SRM input quantification [2][4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity was resolved as HYDRO ALUMINIUM AS (org.nr. 917 537 534) via Proff official registry fields.[1] A DNV verification statement was commissioned by Hydro Aluminium AS and lists Hydro Aluminium AS Norwegian smelter sites, supporting that this is the relevant operating entity for assessed aluminium production inputs.[2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence shows inbound recycled aluminium scrap is used as an input in Hydro Aluminium AS-related casthouse/casting charge mixes (post-consumer and pre-consumer scrap).[2] Hydro also states used aluminium is taken back, remelted, and blended into new aluminium production, with a stated Høyanger recycling capability of about 33,000 t/year distributed to multiple Norwegian plants.[3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium scrap input
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as feed in casthouse/casting charge mixes and remelt-blend routes for new aluminium products in Norwegian plants linked to Hydro Aluminium AS.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is clearly operational (not merely conceptual): verification documentation includes post- and pre-consumer scrap in casting charge material accounting, and Hydro describes industrial remelt/blending plus substantial annual recycling capacity (33,000 t/year at Høyanger facility feeding several plants).[2][3]

main_quantity.context: Hydro states Høyanger Resirkulering can recycle about 33,000 tonnes of used aluminium per year.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The 33,000 t figure is stated as expected site recycling capability ("vil kunne") rather than audited realized annual intake for Hydro Aluminium AS consolidated operations.[3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Public evidence confirms scrap input use and site-level capability, but does not provide a verified realized annual SRM input total specifically at Hydro Aluminium AS legal-entity aggregate level.[2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No public Hydro Aluminium AS legal-entity report was found with realized annual inbound SRM tonnage split by site/material for the same reporting year.[2][3]
Available statements mix legal-entity and business-line/product documentation, so allocation of all recycled input volumes strictly to Hydro Aluminium AS remains partially inferred.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity selected is JØTUL AS (AS), org. no. 989 519 247, on Proff.[1] Norskeutslipp permit documents also identify Jøtul’s Fredrikstad operation and show facility-level org. no. 974284847 linked to the same company context.[4][5]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Jøtul has clear evidence of inbound SRM use: recycled scrap iron is used as feedstock for cast iron manufacturing, and cast iron is central to its products.[2][3] This indicates SRM is core rather than pilot use.[2]

material_examples: Recycled scrap iron from local scrap dealers
Recycled iron feed for cast iron production
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound feedstock to produce cast iron for fireplaces/stoves at the foundry and manufacturing operations.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The annual report states all cast iron production uses recycled iron, and cast-iron fireplaces are core products; this supports significant/core SRM dependence.[2] Additional company text confirms daily scrap-iron deliveries.[3]

share.context: The report states all cast iron production is with recycled iron; treated as a 100% recycled feedstock share for cast-iron production, not total company mass input.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual tonnage of recycled scrap iron input was found in the reviewed public sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The strongest quantified statement is a qualitative 100% share for cast-iron production; absolute mass/energy input volumes are not disclosed publicly in reviewed sources.[2][3] Permit documents confirm cast-iron production context but do not provide SRM input tonnage.[4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-level disclosed tonnage (t/year) for recycled scrap iron input was identified in reviewed annual report, website pages, or permit text.[2][3][4]
Permit text confirms production and environmental framework, but not detailed inbound SRM mass-balance data.[4]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The selected entity is the Norwegian legal company NORSK GJENVINNING AS (AS), org. no. 937270062, on Proff; the company website footer also names Norsk Gjenvinning AS [1][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Norsk Gjenvinning AS shows meaningful inbound SRM use through large-scale intake and processing of waste-derived material streams, including plastics handled by NG Downstream and gypsum waste used to produce gypsum powder for further material recycling [4][2]. Permits also indicate very large intake capacities at Oslo operations, but those streams are mixed and not fully classifiable into one SRM category from public summaries alone [3].

srm_inputs.label: Plastic waste feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Plastic waste is sorted, quality-checked, baled, and sent to recyclers that produce granulate for new products [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company’s downstream division reports handling 25,000 tonnes of plastic annually, indicating meaningful operational scale for recycled plastic input handling [4].

main_quantity.context: Stated as annual plastic volume handled by NG Downstream, described as Norsk Gjenvinning’s market and trading division [4].

other_quantities.context: Listed as approximate annual sub-volume for agricultural film within handled plastic streams [4].
Listed as approximate annual sub-volume for clear film within handled plastic streams [4].
Listed as approximate annual sub-volume for colored film within handled plastic streams [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Publicly disclosed as handled annual volume; treated here as inbound received input to sorting/trading operations [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The disclosed volume includes volumes from NG and external trading customers, so legal-entity-only attribution is not fully explicit [4].

srm_inputs.label: Gypsum waste (construction mineral stream)
srm_inputs.used_for: At Holmestrand, gypsum waste is received and processed (sorting and grinding) to produce gypsum powder for further material recycling by external actors [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: A permit allows intake up to 80,000 tonnes per year, which is a meaningful single-site SRM input scale [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Protan reports inbound use of recycled surplus material in roofing products, with a stated 4.5-6.5% recycled share in 2023 and procedures across production facilities.[2][3]

srm_inputs.uncertainties: The percentage is presented as a range and may vary by product and production site; company-specific tonnage for Protan AS is not disclosed.[2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: Public sources reviewed do not provide Protan AS-specific annual tonnage of recycled input material, only percentage-based statements.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The legal entity is identified as REC Solar Norway AS with organization number 986 707 328 in its EPD documentation [2]. A later Elkem notice states Elkem Testvirksomhet AS was "formerly known as Rec Solar Norway AS," indicating post-transaction renaming/merger context [4]. Accessible Proff hits referred to subunit/renamed entries (not a clear standalone REC Solar Norway AS legal-entity profile), so proff_url is set to null [5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: REC Solar Norway AS shows evidence of inbound secondary silicon feedstock in EPD data for solar-grade silicon: internally sourced recycled silicon (25.5%) and externally sourced recycled silicon (2.6%) [3]. This indicates meaningful SRM use in feedstock mix, but available evidence is percentage-based and historical, without recent annual tonnage [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled silicon feedstock
material_examples: Internally sourced recycled Si (bottom- and top cuts)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as input feedstock in manufacturing solar grade silicon (SoG-Si) [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: EPD data reports 25.5% internally sourced recycled Si and 2.6% externally sourced recycled Si in the total SoG-Si mass, indicating meaningful SRM input share [3].

share.context: The SoG-Si EPD table reports 25.5% internal recycled silicon plus 2.6% external recycled silicon in total mass [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual SRM tonnage is provided in accessible sources; quantification is provided as share percentages in EPD tables [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The EPD percentages are based on declared-product data and may not represent current operations after ownership changes and merger/dissolution steps in 2024 [3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No directly reported annual mass of recycled silicon input (t/year) was found in accessible documents; only percentage shares were available [3].
Entity structure changed after 2024 transactions, which may affect continuity/comparability of SRM input reporting for the same legal entity [4].
Permit material confirms production/NACE context but does not quantify SRM inbound feedstocks [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Entity resolved as the Norwegian legal company RETURKRAFT AS (org. no. 991590463) via Proff and company website footer.[1][2] The permit document is for the same site/operator but shows facility business number 991630538, which is distinct from legal org number.[3]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Returkraft’s core activity is energy recovery from incoming residual waste; the plant receives residual waste from households/businesses and burns it for electricity and district heating.[2][3] Public sources show large inbound volumes (about 130,000 t/year handled; permit framework up to 160,000 t/year), indicating significant/core SRM input use.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Residual waste as solid recovered fuel for energy recovery
material_examples: Special waste fractions sent to incineration
srm_inputs.used_for: Incoming residual waste is combusted in the plant to recover energy as electricity and district heating.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes annual handling of ~130,000 tonnes of residual/special waste and the permit allows very large waste intake for incineration, showing this is a core input stream.[2][3]

main_quantity.context: Company page states annual handled volume of residual and special waste.[2]

other_quantities.context: Permit states maximum total annual waste intake at the plant.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct annual inbound amount is publicly stated on the company page (130,000 t/year), while permit limit is higher (160,000 t/year).[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 130,000 t figure is not explicitly tied to one named reporting year in the page text, and it aggregates residual plus special waste types.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No machine-readable annual report table was accessible here to confirm a year-specific actual inbound tonnage split by waste category.[2]
Permit provides a legal maximum intake (not actual realized intake), so it is treated as permit_limit, not actual use.[3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Entity resolved as Norwegian legal company SPEIRA AS (org.nr. 975 934 578) via Proff. Speira’s 2024 Transparency Act statement confirms Speira AS is one of the two Speira Norway operating companies and has facilities in Holmestrand and Karmøy. [1][2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Speira AS uses recycled aluminium scrap as an inbound production input, with Holmestrand described as producing rolled aluminium products based on remelting recycled and primary aluminium, and 'almost exclusively' on scrap plus ingot metal in the transparency statement. However, full company-wide actual SRM input tonnage is not disclosed in the located sources. [2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium scrap
srm_inputs.used_for: Input feed for remelting/casting in the Holmestrand foundry to produce rolled aluminium products. [2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates substantial use at Holmestrand (including language that production there is almost exclusively based on remelting aluminium scrap and ingot metal), but the legal entity has multiple sites and no audited company-wide SRM input share/tonnage is provided in the retrieved set. [2][3][4]

other_quantities.context: Company press communication states the new Holmestrand furnace will add 22,000 tons scrap intake per year; this is a forward-looking increase, not reported historical actual use. [4]

share.context: Press communication says around half of Holmestrand production will be based on recycled scrap after the new furnace project. [4]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No source found with current, company-level actual annual SRM input mass for Speira AS; available quantified figures are forward-looking site-level statements for Holmestrand. [4]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The transparency statement is common reporting context for Speira AS and Speira Recycling Services Norway AS, and the strongest scrap-use wording is site-specific (Holmestrand). Forward-looking figures may change as the furnace project progresses. [2][4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No retrieved annual report/ESG dataset provided audited, current-year company-level tonnes of recycled scrap input for Speira AS alone. [2][4]
Permit-hearing text confirms recycled aluminium remelting and expected higher scrap intake, but does not provide realized annual SRM mass for the legal entity. [3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Resolved to the Norwegian legal entity ST1 BIOKRAFT AS (AS) with org. no. 894625902 via Proff official company data.[1] Norskeutslipp also lists Biokraft AS (St1 biokraft as) in Levanger with permits (2019, 2023), consistent with the same Norwegian operating entity/site context.[4]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: ST1 Biokraft AS uses waste/residual organic inputs as core inbound feedstock for biogas at Skogn, including fish silage, sewage sludge/food waste context, and industrial process water side-streams.[2][3] Reported inbound handling volume is very large (914,906 tonnes for organic waste/residues/process water in 2023, Business Area Norway), indicating significant SRM dependence.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Organic bio-based residues for anaerobic digestion
srm_inputs.used_for: These residual organic substrates are fed into anaerobic digestion/biogas production at Skogn, where silage from salmon farms is described as a main raw material and sewage sludge/food waste are common substrates in Norway operations.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes these as primary/common substrates and reports very high annual managed inbound volume for organic waste/residues/process water (914,906 tonnes, Norway business area, 2023), supporting a core role.[2]

main_quantity.context: The disclosed figure is presented as "management of organic waste, residues and process water" for Norway/Skogn context; it is used as inbound SRM proxy volume.[2]

other_quantities.context: The Skogn production-page description states fish silage at 70,000 tonnes per year as a primary raw material.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct total inbound mass is available, but it is aggregated together with process water and does not split each substrate type.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Public sources reviewed do not provide audited substrate-by-substrate annual tonnage split for the Norwegian legal entity alone.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Industrial process water side-stream input
material_examples: Process water from pulp and paper industry
srm_inputs.used_for: Process water from Norske Skog's pulp/paper industry is described as a primary raw material input in Skogn biogas production.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: It is explicitly named as primary raw material, indicating meaningful use, but no standalone annual tonnage is publicly disclosed in the reviewed sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No separate quantitative figure for process-water input alone was found in the reviewed company public materials.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The available mass disclosure aggregates process water with other organic inputs, preventing exact A10-only quantification.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: Norskeutslipp indicates permits for Biokraft/St1 Biokraft (2019, 2023), but the underlying permit documents were not accessible in the retrieved pages for extracting permit-limit substrate breakdown.[4]
Public disclosures are mainly at Skogn/Norway business-area level; legal-entity-only SRM split by input stream remains limited.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The selected entity is the Norwegian legal company STEEN-HANSEN AS (AS) with org. no. 982 775 337 on Proff, matching the requested company.[1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Steen-Hansen documents use of copper oxide made from recycled copper pipes/wires/refrigerators in its copper-based net protection products, indicating meaningful inbound SRM metal input use in that product line.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled-copper-derived copper oxide
material_examples: Copper oxide (Cu2O) produced from recycled copper pipes, wires, refrigerators
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as an active antifouling component in copper-based net protection coating/impregnation products.[2][1]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The page states copper oxide is the most used copper form and that it is produced from recycled copper items, supporting meaningful (not merely pilot) inbound use for this product family.[2]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No public numeric data (mass, volume, energy, or share) was found for recycled copper-derived input volumes in available company pages.[2]

revenue.notes: Proff reports operating revenue (Sum driftsinntekter) of 133 000, with amounts stated in thousands of NOK; converted value is NOK 133,000,000.[1]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity was resolved as Veidekke ASA (allmennaksjeselskap) with org number 917 103 801 on Proff.[1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Veidekke discloses inbound use of secondary materials in operations, including recycled steel inputs in Veidekke Prefab and recycled concrete aggregate in concrete initiatives/projects.[2][3][4] Evidence is strongest at business-unit/project level, with limited group-wide volume disclosure.[2][3][4]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled rebar steel in prefab concrete elements
srm_inputs.used_for: Veidekke Prefab states recycled reinforcing steel is used in its production of concrete elements.[2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The statement that only recycled rebar is used indicates established, non-pilot use in that business unit.[2]

share.context: The Prefab page states that only 100% recycled rebar steel is used.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass/energy quantity is disclosed for this input in the reviewed source.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Disclosure is for Veidekke Prefab and may not represent all Veidekke ASA business units.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Scrap-iron-based wire for hollow-core slabs
material_examples: Wire for hollow-core slabs containing scrap iron
srm_inputs.used_for: In Prefab production, wire used for hollow-core slabs is described as containing scrap iron.[2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: An explicit 86% scrap-iron content indicates meaningful integration of secondary metal feedstock in that product input.[2]

share.context: The Prefab page specifies 86% scrap iron content in wire for hollow-core slabs.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Only composition share is disclosed; no annual tonnage is provided.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Scope appears limited to the cited Prefab activity and specific wire application.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled concrete/return masses as aggregate input
srm_inputs.used_for: Veidekke sources describe use of recycled aggregate in concrete and replacement of virgin aggregate with recycled concrete in a pilot context.[2][3][4]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence includes pilot and project-level implementation (e.g., Ulven pilot and specific project descriptions), but lacks company-wide scale data.[3][4]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: The reviewed sources provide qualitative/project-level statements, but no direct annual quantity of recycled aggregate input.[2][3][4]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Some statements are pilot-oriented and may not indicate routine use across all projects or all business units.[3][4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No group-level annual tonnage (t/kg) or energy-volume data for SRM inbound inputs was found in the reviewed public sources.[2][3][4]
Several SRM claims are business-unit or pilot/project specific, limiting certainty about total Veidekke ASA-wide SRM input share.[2][3][4]

employees.notes: Proff lists 25 employees on the company overview page, but no explicit reporting year is shown next to the employee figure [1].

revenue.notes: Proff reports 2024 operating revenue as 5,448,218 with amounts stated in thousands (NOK), converted here to NOK 5,448,218,000 [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Proff page is a unit page, but it explicitly points to the main entity (hovedenhet) VEIDEKKE INDUSTRI AS with organization number 913 536 770; this was used as the legal-entity anchor [1]. Statsforvalteren also names Veidekke Industri AS directly for asphalt/returasfalt operations [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Veidekke Industri AS has documented inbound use of reclaimed asphalt (returasfalt) as an input to asphalt production. A Statsforvalteren case states receipt/crushing of up to 5,000 tonnes annually for reuse in its asphalt production, and Veidekke discloses major projects where about half of asphalt volume contains recycled asphalt [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Reclaimed asphalt (returasfalt)
material_examples: Crushed recycled asphalt from old road sections
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as recycled mineral/asphalt input in new asphalt production at Veidekke asphalt plants [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence shows explicit operational reuse in asphalt production and large-project deployment with substantial recycled share; this indicates meaningful SRM use rather than only pilot activity [2][3].

main_quantity.context: A Statsforvalteren hearing text states an application for receiving/crushing up to 5,000 tonnes returasfalt annually for reuse in asphalt production at Sigerfjord [2].

share.context: For a major E10 contract, Veidekke states about half of asphalt volume will contain recycled asphalt from the old road section [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Direct company-wide SRM intake totals were not found; available quantified evidence is site/project specific (5,000 t/year application in Sortland and ~50% recycled share in an E10 project) [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 5,000 t figure is from a hearing/application text and not a confirmed measured annual intake. The E10 disclosure is a Veidekke group press release and does not explicitly name the legal entity in the quote [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No consolidated annual tonnage of recycled asphalt input for the full legal entity was located in accessible public sources [2][3].
No directly accessible annual/sustainability PDF table for Veidekke Industri AS with entity-level SRM input breakdown was retrievable from the crawled sources [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Matched the Norwegian legal entity by exact legal name and organization number on Proff [1]. Yara Norge AS also states its transparency disclosure refers to Yara International ASA's integrated disclosure, which is used as supporting SRM context [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates meaningful SRM input use in Yara's integrated reporting (byproduct/waste-stream raw materials and recycled plastic packaging), but the report does not provide a Yara Norge AS-only split [2][3]. srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The integrated report states 1,933 thousand tonnes of byproduct/waste-stream raw materials and 21.5% of raw material inflows (excluding feedstock), indicating meaningful use, but not disaggregated to Yara Norge AS [3].

main_quantity.context: Reported as procured raw materials based on byproducts or waste streams from suppliers in 2024 [3].

share.context: Share is reported as percent of raw material inflows excluding feedstock [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Quantity and share are explicitly reported, but at Yara integrated-report scope rather than legal-entity level for Yara Norge AS [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: No explicit split by Norwegian legal entity, site, or business unit is provided for these byproduct/waste-stream inputs [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic used in product packaging
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound packaging material for Yara product bags in Europe [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The report documents implementation (30% recycled plastic bags in Europe; 4,427 tonnes recycled plastic in 2024), but this is packaging input and not disclosed specifically for Yara Norge AS [3].

main_quantity.context: Reported recycled plastic use in 2024 related to packaging initiatives [3].

share.context: Report states all bags in Europe were changed to 30% recycled plastic [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct mass quantity exists, but entity-level allocation to Yara Norge AS is not disclosed [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Geographic statement is Europe-wide and may include operations outside Norway; no site/entity allocation is provided [3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The integrated report provides company-wide data, not a legal-entity breakdown for Yara Norge AS [2][3].
No permit/about-page evidence found that quantifies SRM inbound inputs specifically for Yara Porsgrunn or Yara Glomfjord [4].
SRM evidence is strongest for group-level procurement and packaging initiatives; applicability to Yara Norge AS is inferred but not directly quantified [2][3].
